Range staff and other roles

 

The RSO must supervise all other people at the range who may be assisting or observing:

 

•Assistant RSO

•Range staff

•Coaches

Supervision

Safety Equipment

•Safety glasses - The wearing of safety glasses or shatterproof eyeglasses is mandatory when firing air rifles except during biathlon training/competition. Hearing protection can also be worn voluntarily.

•First aid - RSO will ensure a first aider and a first aid kit are at the firing point.

 

Vigilance

During range activities, RSO must be:

•present,

•alert, and

•aware.

 

Read the
“Top 10 supervision mistakes that RSO make”

 

Present – RSO must be at the firing point when firing is taking place. Accidents can happen in just seconds so the RSO must be physically close enough to the firing point to personally intervene. Should the RSO have to leave the firing point, then all firing must cease.

Alert – RSO need to stay focused on the firing activity taking place. Eliminate distractions, keep the firing point and area directly behind it clear of obstacles and clutter, and just concentrate on the safety of the participants. Let coaches assist the shooters, and assign range assistants to take care of the routine tasks like ammunition and targets.

Aware – RSO must watch for changes to the range environment, any people who try to enter the range area (especially non-participants who may not be aware that shooting is taking place) and monitor the health and behaviour of participants.

An assistant RSO is an adult staff member whose responsibility it is to aid the RSO with their supervisory duties on the range. Usually, an RSO will employ assistants on activities that have many participants at the firing point at the same time.

Range staff can include:

 

Ammunition party – person(s) responsible for counting, controlling and distributing pellets on the range (when directed by the RSO).

 

Sentry – person(s) assigned to restrict/control access to the range (danger template area), or to change the flag/light when directed by the RSO. Sentries must have communication with the RSO.

 

Firing Point Assistant – person(s) assigned tasks by the RSO that are not directly related to safety (e.g. moving equipment between relays, administration, scoring, etc.).

Coaches – person(s) tasked to coach the participant, and may be situated beside or behind the participant. Coaches must minimize their movements on the firing point.

 

Safety glasses

Safety glasses or shatter-proof prescription glasses are worn at the firing point, and in the area directly behind it, during all shooting.

First Aid requirements

 

The RSO will ensure that:

 

•at least one qualified Standard First Aider is present at the firing point;

•first aid equipment is at the firing point (e.g. first aid kit, and if available, a stretcher and blanket);

•emergency contact information for participants is available (e.g. parents / guardians); and

•information regarding cadet medication and allergies is available (especially food or insect allergies).

•Getting distracted during firing by a non-safety related event or question.

•Standing too far away from the firing line to intervene when a safety hazard occurs.

•Trying to be a coach and RSO at the same time.

•Allowing participants to remove safety glasses because they are uncomfortable or fogging up.

•Failing to keep watch over the access points to the range and someone enters the danger area.

•Briefly leaving the firing point to quickly grab something they forgot.

•Talking with another person and not concentrating on the activity taking place.

•Losing focus during a long activity.

•Overlooking disruptive or unsafe behaviour of a participant.

•Allowing extra people who don’t have a direct role or responsibility to be at the firing point.

Top 10 supervision mistakes that RSO make:
